metadata.title: Disorders of Consciousness, Minimally Conscious State  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: minimally conscious state, disorders of consciousness  occupational therapy
anatomical location body part affected: The brain; the entire individual is affected by disorders of consciousness
description: Disorders of consciousness include coma, unresponsive wakefulness syndrome (UWS), and minimally conscious state (MCS)

Coma –The patient has no awareness of the environment or themselves(33) –Consciousness is depressed and the eyes remain closed(1,2) –While in a coma, the patient is unarousable; however, they may exhibit some reflexive movements(1) –A major complication of serious disorders of the CNS(1)

UWS –Typically follows coma(2) –The patient shows improvement from initial comatose state; however, they typically appear awake (e.g., eyes open) but remain motionless and without awareness of surroundings(1,35) –Previously this state was referred to as a vegetative state. However, in 2010 Laureys et al. proposed a change in the terminology to unresponsive wakefulness syndromebecause vegetative state was considered pejorative. The European Task Force on Disorders of Consciousness then passed a proposal to implement the change. Most literature published since then uses the term UWS(36)

MCS –A significantly altered state of consciousness distinct from coma and UWS due to presence of episodes of consciousness in which eye contact or goal-directed  behavior occurs(2) –Individuals in an MCS demonstrate inconsistent periods of consciousness and show some degree of functional recovery as well as responsive behavior(1) –Behavioral responses of individuals in an MCS indicate some level of self-awareness and awareness of the environment(1) -Behavioral responses of individuals in an MCS include basic verbalizations, context-appropriate  gestures, emotionally appropriate responses (e.g., smiles), and purposeful movements (e.g., hand movements or eye blinks) in response to environmental stimuli(1)

This Clinical Review focuses on patients in an MCS. For detailed information about coma and UWS, please see  Clinical Review…Disorders of Consciousness: Coma and Unresponsive Wakefulness Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709285

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. In order to be reimbursable by an insurance company, therapy is required to be medically necessary and the patient must be likely to make functional improvements as a result of therapy
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients in MCS will be able to show some signs of self- or environmental awareness by demonstrating ≥ 1 of the following:(37) –command following –gestural or verbal yes/no responses (regardless of accuracy) –intelligible verbalization –purposeful behavior (not due to reflexive activity), including -appropriate smiling or crying in response to linguistic content or visual content of emotional stimuli -vocalizations or gestures in direct response to linguistic content of questions -reaching for objects in a way that shows clear relationship between object location and direction of reach -touching or holding objects in a way that accommodates the object size and shape -pursuit eye movement with sustained fixation in direct response to moving or salient stimuli
Patients in disordered states of consciousness typically develop joint contractures and decubitus ulcers over time as a result of being bedbound(1,4)

Locked-in  syndrome (de-efferentedstate)(1) –Locked-in  syndrome presents similarly to a disorder of consciousness and must be differentiated from a UWS and MCS. In locked-in  syndrome, patients are conscious and aware of their surroundings but unable to speak or move –Caused by acute destructive lesions of the brainstem that damage the ventral pons while sparing the tegmentum –Typically, the prognosis for patients with locked-in  syndrome is poor; however, recovery has been reported, including return to independence in ADLs Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: In an evaluation of a patient in an MCS, the examiner is attempting to elicit behavioral responses through various types of stimulation; therefore, there is a risk that the patient could become agitated and/or combative

causes: an mcs can result from several: Traumatic brain injury (TBI)(1,2,5,6)–For detailed information on TBI, see the series of Clinical Reviews  on this topic
Metabolic disturbances (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis, hepatic encephalopathy)(1)
Anoxia(5,6,7)–Anoxia can result from cardiac arrest, drug or alcohol overdose, or other events(1,7,32)
Stroke(5,6,7)–For detailed information on occupational therapy for patients who have had a stroke, see the series of Clinical Reviews  onthis topic
Asphyxiation (as a result of hanging, drowning, or carbon monoxide or other gas poisoning)(8)
pathogenesis: the disturbance of conscio: Structural lesions of the brain causing bilateral cerebral dysfunction
Damage to the brainstem reticular activating system

overall contraindications precautions: An occupational therapy assessment should include the patient and family/friends as appropriate; including the patient’s familial and social network in the rehabilitation process may assist in the patient’s psychosocial recovery(9)
For patients in an MCS, monitor for signs/symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), observe seizure precautions, and take care transferring and positioning a patient who has decubitus ulcers
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: In an evaluation of a patient in an MCS, the examiner is attempting to elicit behavioral responses through various types of stimulation; therefore, there is a risk that the patient could become agitated and/or combative

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical chart and physician reports to ascertain information about the patient’s underlying condition -What caused the patient to be in an MCS? What circumstances surrounded the onset of the MCS?(1) -How long has the patient been in an MCS?(1) Was the patient in a coma prior to the MCS? If so, for how long? Have there been any medical complications up to this point? Are there any comorbid injuries or conditions? -Review the patient’s medical chart to determine if the physician has made a statement regarding long-term  prognosis for consciousness(1)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical and surgical management of the patient’s medical condition to date. Medical management of swelling in the face and head; monitoring intracranial pressure (ICP)(1) craniotomy (e.g., evacuation of hematoma, placement of a ventriculoperitoneal [VP] shunt)(1) airway management/intubation/mechanical ventilation(1) induced therapeutic hypothermia, which is often used with patients who arrive at the hospital in a coma to prevent further neurological damage(8) placement of a feeding tube (nasogastric [NG] or gastric [G] tube)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; how are they being taken? IV or feeding tube? Any treatable conditions (based on physical exam and laboratory findings) should be addressed with medications(38) The 2018 American Academy of Neurology practice guidelines for patients with disorders of consciousness state that amantadine (100200  mg twice daily) for adults with traumatic UWS or MCS (416  weeks post injury) may hasten functional recovery and reduce disability when administered early in recovery(39)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Diagnostic imaging (e.g., MRI, CT scan, chest X-ray)(1,10)
Blood work (CBC, platelets, PT[INR], PTT, BUN, creatinine, serum glucose, electrolyte analysis, arterial blood gases [ABGs], toxicologic studies as indicated)(1)
Event-related  potentials (ERPs) are measured with an EEG and sometimes used to establish prognosis(11)
A lack of somatosensory evoked potentials (SEPs) is associated with an unfavorable prognosis for return to full consciousness(11)
Functional neuroimaging to assess cerebral metabolism(11,12)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they improve responsiveness
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document the patient’s response to stimuli such as light, sound, touch, and pain.(1) Document if the family/caregiver/nurse reports anything that appears to either calm or agitate the patient
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use Oucher, FLACC scale, Adult Nonverbal Pain Scale (NVPS), Behavioral Pain Scale, or Critical Care Pain Observation Tool to document pain response -Note the behavioral response to painful stimuli(1) -Purposeful limb withdrawal from painful stimuli suggests that the patient’s sensory pathways from and motor pathways to the limb are intact(1) -An absence of behavioral response to pain unilaterally suggests presence of a corticospinal lesion(1) -An absence of a response to pain bilaterally suggests damage to/involvement of the brainstem, bilateral pyramidal tract lesions, or psychogenic unresponsiveness(1)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: In an MCS, the patient will exhibit a clear sleep-wake  cycle (unlike patients in UWS or coma). Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient is experiencing -Risk of DVT is significantly increased in patients with hemiplegia and other motor impairments; assess for signs of DVT (e.g., redness, warmth, tenderness, swelling) and report to physician urgently if these symptoms are present
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? Type and settings? Document history of weaning attempts where

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  In order to appropriately assess an individual in an MCS, therapists at the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (now known as the Shirley Ryan AbilityLab)recommend ensuring optimal conditions for evaluation, including administering adequate stimulation to maximize level of arousal, appropriately addressing factors that may affect arousal prior to evaluation (e.g., sedating medications, appropriate timing for the evaluation), eliciting behavioral responses with verbal instructions, not solely documenting reflexive behaviors, ensuring that activities elicited in testing are within the patient’s ability according to prior level of function (i.e., age- and developmentally appropriate), attempting to elicit a variety of behavioral responses with a large range of stimuli, conducting evaluations in an environment free of distractions, performing frequent reassessments to document changes in functioning, and using input from family members, caregivers, and other staff members(13)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: For patients in an MCS, assistive and adaptive devices may not be beneficial due to reduced purposeful and intentional movements. However, for the patient who is regaining the ability to control even small movements such as eye blinks or hand closure, assistive technology can be introduced in order for the patient to communicate (e.g., make a request) or act on his or her environment (e.g., change the radio station)(9,14,15)
relevant tests and measures.balance: The vestibular-ocular  reflex of a patient in an MCS can be assessed by caloric stimulation using irrigation with ice water(1) –Document the results of any caloric stimulation; this is typically performed by a physician or audiologist, not an occupational therapist (OT) –Assess balance in sitting position for any patient in or emerging from an MCS
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post stimulation
Monitor respiratory rate to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesAssess patient for involvement of cranial and peripheral nerves –Ipsilateral pupillary dilation with no direct or consensual response to light indicates damage to the 3rd cranial nerve and can occur with herniation of the brain(1) –The vestibular-ocular  reflex of a patient in an MCS can be assessed by caloric stimulation using irrigation with ice water; this test assesses the function of the 8th cranial nerve(1)
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Is patient able to assist with bed mobility or positioning?Assess joint integrity and mobility  –Assess upper extremity active (if possible) and passive ROM (AROM/PROM) -Note hyper-  and hypomobility as well as soft tissue changes such as swelling, inflammation, and restriction at the shoulder, elbow, wrist, and fingers –Joint contractures can develop over time as a result of prolonged disuse and bedbound status(1,4)Assess fine and gross motor function, if any, of the upper extremities. Document primitive reflexes with the use of standardized testing, if available –Neuromuscular impairments are common in individuals in UWSs and MCSs(16) -Document the presence of hemiplegia, spasticity, or flaccidity(1) –Tone may fluctuate secondary to changes in position, medications, illness, volitional movement, emotional state, pain, and environmental factors(33) –Modified Ashworth Scale (mAS) -Used to assess tone -Severity of spasticity can be graded on the mAS
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers, if possible; do not perform MMT with muscles with contractures or muscles with abnormal tone or coordination issues. Strength assessment through functional movement may be appropriate -Patients who have been bedbound for long periods due to disorders of consciousness typically exhibit significant muscle weakness throughout the body(16) –Assess grip and pinch strength, if possible
observation inspection palpation includi: Skin breakdown can develop over time in patients who are in an MCS as a result of prolonged bedbound status(1,4)

Observe for and document presence of abnormalities in skin integrity (e.g., redness, dark or purple spots, shiny skin, skin that doesn’t blanch when pressed) or skin breakdown upon initial evaluation and at the start of each treatment session; report new or changing skin breakdown to patient’s nurse and/or physician
Measure and stage any skin breakdown/decubitus ulcers
Monitor for DVT and document the presence of any redness, warmth, or swelling in the legs
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document posture and abnormal posturing –Decorticate posturing (the individual is stiff, with arms flexed in toward the body, clenched fists sometimes held on the chest, and legs extended) can occur when there are lesions of the internal capsule and rostral cerebral peduncle(1) –Decerebrate posturing (arms extended and internally rotated, legs extended with feet plantar flexed, and head and neck arched backwards) occurs when there is extensive brainstem damage that extends to the pons at the level of the trigeminal nerve(1) -Decerebrate posturing can be accompanied by flaccidity or slight flexor responses in the patient’s legs(1)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess PROM (and AROM, if possible) of both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers –Note pain response with any active movement or stretching –Document presence of contractures
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Document the presence of primitive reflexes (e.g., bite, grasp); document presence of any abnormal reflexesFIM can be used to document the patient’s level of assistance for ADLs; however, for most individuals in an MCS, total assistance will be required for all aspects of self-care –Informal assessment of ADLs can include giving the patient an object, such as a hairbrush, spoon, or mirror, and asking him or her how this would be used(13)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Examine for sensory impairment using stimulation such as pinprick, temperature changes, pressure, proprioception, and vibration
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers who surveyed OTs who work with children with disorders of consciousness found that OTs typically use assessments designed for adults to assess children in a UWS or MCS. Most therapists reported dissatisfaction with this practice, as these assessments do not necessarily provide the therapist with the information needed for planning treatment for a pediatric patient with such a complex condition(3) -Adults generally respond to a wider range of stimuli than children; for pediatric patients, it is essential that familiar voices (such as those of the child’s parents or siblings) and familiar toys and objects be used during assessment whenever possible(13) –A task force with members from the American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine Brain Injury–Interdisciplinary Special(recommended, with minor reservations)(28) -A standardized behavioral assessment that measures neurobehavioral function to assist with differential diagnosis and document recovery from coma. Comprises 23 items that are divided among 6 subscales; assesses auditory, visual, motor, oromotor, communication, and arousal functions(41) -Considered the most validated and sensitive method for identifying behavioral signs of awareness that can help distinguish between UWS, MCS, and emergence of the MCS(41) -Misdiagnosis between coma, UWS, and minimally conscious states is common. Authors of a study found that the number of assessments (CRS-S)  had a significant effect on the clinical diagnosis in disorders of consciousness. They found that the results of one to four assessments of the CRS-S were statistically different from results of the reference diagnosis, which was based on the sixth assessment. They recommended a minimum of five CSR-R  assessments be conducted within a short time interval (e.g., 2 weeks) to reduce misdiagnosis(40) T709271 -Coma/Near-Coma  Scale (CNC) (recommended, with major reservations)(28) -Disorders of Consciousness Scale (DOCS) (recommended, with moderate reservations)(28) -A standardized assessment with 23 test items; each item is rated on a 3-point  scale(11,13) -0 = No response; response does not differ from baseline behavior; 1 = General response; 2 = Localized response; response is contextually related to the test stimuli -The DOCS manual and testing forms are available free in the public domain -Sensory Modality Assessment Technique (SMART) (recommended, with moderate reservations)(28)  -A valid and reliable assessment tool for individuals in a disordered state of consciousness; includes 8 subscales, with 5 possible ratings for each item; to be used as both an assessment and treatment tool(11,18) -Sensory Stimulation Assessment Measure (SSAM) (recommended, with moderate reservations)(28) -Wessex Head Injury Matrix (WHIM) (recommended, with moderate reservations)(28) -Western Neuro Sensory Stimulation Profile (WNSSP) (recommended, with moderate reservations)(28) –According to the ACRM BI-ISIG,  the Swedish Reaction Level Scale–1985  (RLS85), Loewenstein Communication Scale (LOEW), and Comprehensive Levels of Consciousness Scale (CLOCS) are not recommended for serial bedside behavioral assessment of persons with disorders of consciousness(28) –According to the ACRM BI-ISIG,  the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Innsbruck Coma Scale (ICS), and Full Outline of UnResponsiveness (FOUR) Score are not recommended for serial bedside behavioral assessment of persons with disorders of consciousness because expert consensus finds that these scales’ items do not satisfactorily cover a representative sample of disorders of consciousness behavior and have unacceptably low levels of standardization in their administration and scoring procedures(28)A scale created for use with patients in various states of consciousness; score (can range from 3 to 15) is based on motor responsiveness, verbal performance, and eye opening to appropriate stimuli(17)No eye opening, no ability to follow commands, no word verbalizations -Head injury classificationsevere head injurymoderate head injurymild head injury -ICS(17) -A coma scale similar to the GCS; however, the ICS does not rate verbal response and contains additional items forpupillary size and reaction, movement and position of the eyes, and oral automatisms. Scores range from 0 to 23An assessment tool for individuals in a state of disordered consciousness; the scale used to calculate the FOUR score includes 4 testable components, with a maximum of 4 points in each section(19) -The FOUR Score has been found to reliably differentiate locked-in  syndrome from other disorders of consciousness(19) –Coma scales cannot be used to accurately predict functional, long-term  outcome for individuals in an MCS; instead, they are used to describe the patient’s current level of functioning and track changes over time with repeated administrations(17) Standardized assessment tools may not be sensitive to patient-specific  indicators of awareness. Detailed behavioral assessment at specified intervals may improve accuracy of diagnosis and recognition of late recovery(34) –The Reuth Disorders of Consciousness Response Assessment (RDOC-RA)  was designed to be used in conjunction with standardized tools. It has two components, an assessment tool (DOC Movement Checklist) and a documentation tool developed from the assessment that is patient specific (DOC Response Profile) –Case studies are used to illustrate the clinical utility of the RDOC-RA  tool. In the first case, the RDOC-RA  showed the patient to be at a higher level of function than the CRS-R because the movement the patient was able to use to consistently respond to questions was not one included on the standardized test (i.e., use of supported elbow movement to respond). In the second case study, the use of consistent periodic reassessment showed new responses at 19 months post injury. Occupational therapy, which had been discontinued, was started again and the patient progressed to the point of using his hand for switches and writing single words
relevant tests and measures.perception: Traditional assessments of vision and hearing are unlikely to be appropriate for a patient in an MCS; however, document behavioral responses to sound and light(1) –Document pupillary reaction to light(1) -Small but reactive pupils can indicate bilateral diencephalic damage or damage to the brainstem at the level of the pons(1) -Ipsilateral pupillary dilation with no direct or consensual response to light indicates damage to the 3rd cranial nerve and can occur with herniation of the brain(1) -With metabolic encephalopathy, the pupils may be smaller than expected but responsive to light(1) -For patients in an MCS as a result of drug overdose, pupils may be fixed and dilated(1) -Pupillary dilation for several hours after cardiac arrest is associated with a poor overall prognosis(1) –Conjugate deviation (the eyes move to the same side when at rest) indicates an ipsilateral lesion of the cerebral cortex or a contralateral lesion of the brainstem at the level of the pons(1) -Eyes moving downward in conjugate deviation indicates a mesencephalic lesion(1) -Dysconjugate deviation of the eyes indicates a structural lesion of the brainstem (unless the individual had a preexisting strabismus)(1) –Document the position of the eyes and their movement in response to passive movement of the patient’s head(1) -With movement of the head side to side or in flexion and extension, the eyes of a patient in an MCS may exhibit a “doll’s-head  eye response”(1) -In the doll’s-head  eye response, the eyes conjugately deviate in the direction opposite from the head’s movement(1) -This does not occur in individuals with intact consciousness(1)  -The absence of the doll’s-head  eye response indicates dysfunction of brainstem or oculomotor nerves(1)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document level of arousal and awareness. See Special tests specific to diagnosis , below, for tests that measure arousal and awareness in patients with disordered consciousness. Document the results of any diagnostic tests that have been completed to determine level of consciousness and/or prognosis for return of consciousness

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Coma stimulation programs should provide stimulation that does not interfere with the patient’s medical care; for example, sensory stimulation should not result in a dangerous increase in ICP or blood pressure(20)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The OT must consider the patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy; a multifaceted, multidisciplinary approach is indicated for patients who are in an MCS
prognosis: According to the 2018 review by the American Academy of Neurology, in patients with prolonged disorders of consciousness those in whom MCS is diagnosed within the first 5 months of injury have a more favorable long-term prognosis for functional recovery than those in whom UWSis diagnosed(39)
In an Italian population study with 600 patients in either a UWS or an MCS, researchers found that the 10-year  survival rate for those patients in an MCS was 4.8%(32)
Likelihood of significant functional improvement decreases with time
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to dietician, as the patient may be at risk for malnutrition; patient may require nutritional supplements or supplemental feedings Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if the patient’s family is having difficulty coping and/or may benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement Referral to an orthotist for the fabrication of splints, orthoses, braces, etc. (if the splints or orthoses cannot be fabricated by the OT) Referral to physical therapy for evaluation and possible treatment Referral to speech therapy for evaluation and possible treatment
other considerations: Major changes in responsiveness may occur a year or more post-injury; therefore, continued periodic assessments should be considered to ensure that neurologic changes are identified(34)

Visual pursuit (VP) and visual fixation (VF) are often considered signs of emerging consciousness. However, authors of a literature review found that due to lack of consensus on definitions and assessment methods,there continues to be controversy regarding whether VP and VF are truesigns of MCS. They found that the most sensitive method for determining VP and VF was use of a mirror(46)

Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS): InrTMS painless, noninvasive stimulation of the brain with low-frequency  magnetic fields is performed to create electrical currents in specific regions of the brain(24,25,26) –Applying rTMS to a specific part of the undamaged hemisphere of the brain can suppress the inhibitory process of that area and allow for reactivation of some areas within the damaged hemisphere, thereby promoting functional recovery(25) –In a case study in Italy, rTMS was associated with minimal clinical improvements and increased brain activity demonstrated on the EEG of a 70-year-old  male patient who was in an MCS following a large right hemispheric hemorrhage 4 years earlier.(24) Further research is necessary to determine the effectiveness of rTMS for individuals in an MCS
treatment summary: Treatment summary: The purpose of occupational therapy for patients who are in an MCS is to provide stimulation with the goals of promoting neuro-recovery  and decreasing functional decay of the extremities as a result of disuse. There is no current universally accepted evidence-based  treatment for UWS –The American Academy of Neurology practice guidelines for patients with disorders of consciousness state that because most studies are open-label  studies and case reports, results need to be interpreted with caution and cannot be translated directly into practice(39)  –According to the national clinical guideline for brain injury rehabilitation in adults from the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN), there is insufficient evidence regarding nonpharmacological interventions for patients in a UWS or an MCS to support a clinical guideline for practice. The evidence reviewed indicated some positive outcomes for multisensory stimulation, music therapy, contingent stimulation, and assistive technology; however, the quality of the evidence was not high enough to establish treatment efficacy(42) –Authors of a systematic review of studies conducted between 2003 and 2013 on the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions for persons with disordered consciousness found 12 interventions (some of these were nutrition, tracheostomy care, mobility management, and multimodal sensory stimulation) and found insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of multimodal sensory stimulation(35) –The goal of therapeutic coma stimulation or coma arousal programs is to ensure that the patient is receiving holistic care following severe damage to the brain, not just the routine medical care to maintain the functions of the body.(20) Typically, stimulation programs involve intense multimodal stimulation through all five senses.(20,22) Stimulation that has personal meaning to the patient is most effective (e.g., favorite songs, familiar items or routines, pictures) and should be incorporated as much as possible into the treatment.(33) In addition to providing sensory and physical stimulation, OTs might be asked to see patients in an MCS for casting or positioning splints/orthoses and selecting assistive technology devices.OTs also have a role in recognizing unique patient responses (which are sometimes missed on standardized assessments) for ongoing assessment and treatment(34) –Suggestions for occupational therapy for patients in a state of disordered consciousness have been provided by therapists in the intensive therapy unit of the St. George’s Hospital (formerly the Atkinson Morley Hospital) in the United Kingdom:(20) -Begin with passive stimulation (e.g., music, upper extremity massage); move to active stimulation requiring response from the patient (e.g., using therapy bands or therapy putty to elicit a grasping or pulling response) as soon as the patient appears able -Start active rehabilitation as soon as the patient is medically stable per physician order -Provide intense, varied, and consistent stimulation for the patient throughout the duration of the hospital stay -Do not underestimate the intensity of stimulation that may be required to elicit a response from the patient (while monitoring vital signs for undesired effects such as a dangerous increase in ICP, heart or respiratory rate, or blood pressure) -Provide explanations and instructions about providing stimulation for the patient’s family members and friends at bedside –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers performed retrospective chart reviews documenting dependency levels and physiotherapy interventions in 10 patients who were in a UWS or an MCS over a 3-year  period. Interventions included manual stretching, passive ROM exercises, casting/splinting, botulinum toxin injections, and weight-bearing/standing  exercises (when possible). None of the patients included in the chart review emerged from UWS or MCS. All the patients remained fully dependent for self-care;  however, caregiver burden was reduced following physiotherapy interventions, and all patients reached the point of being able to sustain a seated regimen. In the joints addressed in therapy, there was no minimal clinically significant difference in 85 of 120 joint ranges measured (70.8%). Positive changes were observed in 14 joints (11.7%) and negative outcomes in 21 joints (17.5%)(31) –Sensory stimulation -Authors of an RCT (N = 50) evaluated the effectiveness of a tilt table therapy with or without an integrated stepping device on the level of consciousness in patients with UWS or MCS. Both groups received 10 1-hour  verticalization treatments over the course of 3 weeks(43) -Both groups improved significantly on the CRS-R score during the intervention phase and maintained this gain during the follow-up  period -When comparing the changes in the CRS-R  score in the first three weeks and at six weeks, the group receiving therapy on a tilt table without an integrated stepping device group was statistically superior to the group receiving therapy on a tilt table therapy with an integrated stepping device -The group receiving therapy on a tilt table therapy with an integrated stepping device did not have any additional benefit for patients with disorders of consciousness. However, verticalization may be beneficial to patients with disorders of consciousness and is recommended as a treatment early in rehabilitation -For detailed information about tilt tables, please see  Clinical Review … Tilt Table  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709278  –Splinting/orthosis fabrication -Use of appropriate splinting/orthoses can prevent contractures and/or decrease spasticity(44) –Splints described in research studies with patients with disorders of consciousness include: -prefabricated foam splints -footboards/foot-drop  splints -adaptive shoes -Ankle-foot  splint –Facilitating postural changes -Changing a patient’s position can increase the patient’s level of arousal(23) -Positional changes can also prevent hypovolemia, reduce the risk of skin breakdown in bedbound patients, improve the respiratory system, and change resting muscle length(23) –Assistive technology -The OT can assist in the selection of assistive technology devices for communication and functional independence by determining which behavioral responses (e.g., eye blinks, thumb movements, mouth movements) are the most consistent for the individual patient(9,14,15,29) -Microswitches can be connected to a range of devices (e.g., radio, computer, television) for the patient to control his or her environment and communicate needs and wants(9,14,15,29) -Virtual reality (VR) may be an effective diagnostic and/or neurorehabilitation tool -Authors of a case study and literature review evaluated how the effects of VRon brain activity can be monitored by EEG to both assist in correct diagnosis of level of consciousness and improve the level of consciousness of patients(45) -MCS was diagnosed in a 17-year-old  female following a car accident. She received VR treatments twice a week for 5 months. The treatment sessions followed this protocol: -Ten minutes of relaxing screens -Fifteen minutes of screens with familiar objects (e.g., animals, common objects) -Fifteen minutes of screens of colored geometric figures -Ten minutes of cool-down  relaxing screens -More intentional responses were recorded during the training sessions and alsoobjectively seen in the EEG monitoring -The EEG data was able to confirm the diagnosis of MCS for this patient through the intentional modulation of her brain activity in response to VR training –Reality orientation with post-comatose  patients -Immediately upon emerging from a coma, UWS, or MCS, patients typically are confused, disorientated, amnesic, and aphasic and often cognitively impaired(21,27) -Occupational therapy for these patients initially focuses on reorientation(21) -Ask the family to provide familiar, personal objects such as a poster, stuffed animal, or photographs -Posting a calendar in the room and changing it daily can help reorient the patient to time -Provide emotional support as needed and refer to social work/mental health professional when appropriate .
